ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned more about Chinese culture and got more fluent with the language.

I developed my critical thinking skills in Mandarin. By learning more specific and specialized vocabulary in art, history, and other areas of Chinese culture, I was able to express my ideas in a way that reflected what I thought in English. The topics we learned were all relevant to current-day Chinese social trends and attitudes, and I often found myself being able to talk about topics such as Chinese musicians, artists, political movements, and more at the weekly Chinese table.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lots and lots of writing + lots of feedback on your writing = you get better at writing. The class is fun!

I think the key strength of this class lies in the diversity of its course content: assignments may include watching documentaries, reading articles, visits to the YUAG, and writing calligraphy with real materials, and topics range from Chinese fashion and political art to Peking opera and rock music. We were also able to have talks with experts in certain topics; for instance, we had a Zoom with Peking opera actors, and we had an in-person talk with Professor Zhengguo Kang on political dissent. I think the workload is a little on the heavy sidewe are asked to create a digital book of all of our writings from the semester, and mine ended up being around 50 pages. While the Chinese content with which we engage is diverse and plentiful, it also means we have to write often and write extensively on the content.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to anyone who want to learn about Chinese culture, especially the more on the humanities side. Be prepared for a lot of writing assignments though.

Yes, I would recommend this course to any student who feels they are at a level of Chinese where they are mostly fluent but want to gain a deeper understanding of Chinese culture as well as a more specialized set of vocabulary to match it. The course units are all very relevant and are things native Chinese people would be interested in or talk about in their free time.
